--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ron Jeffries <ronjeffries@X...> wrote:

> Dave, as I read the JUnit text it is saying that the classes under 
> test are the fixture, not that the TestCase subclass is the fixture. 
> You seem to be saying that the TestCase subclass is the fixture.

I'm saying that the TestCase subclasses define & embody the fixture. 
The realization of the fixture (in an instance of the TestCase
subclass)  is the collection of objects that are under test.  Note
that the fixture is not just the objects, but their state as well. 
You may have instance of the same classes, but with different state
(e.g. empty list, one element, two elements...). They are different
fixtures and should be in different TestCase subclasses.

This is a bit of a quibble IMHO.  My point is that you don;t mix
fixtures in a single TestCase subclass.... the idea of building
TestCase subclasses around distinct fixtures.

Dave
